awd_titl_txt: SUSCHEM - RING OPENING POLYMERIZATION IN AQUEOUS DISPERSION
awd_abstract_narration:
Polymers are long-chain molecules that consist of a repeating chemical structural unit.  With over 300 million ton produced annually in the form of plastics, polymers are truly ubiquitous to our society. Unfortunately, most of these polymers are not biodegradable, and even if a fraction is recycled, eventually most polymers end up in a landfill, which is an unsustainable and environmentally taxing proposition.  Polymers are synthesized using a chemical reaction called "polymerization."  Emulsion polymerization is a very common industrial technique used for the production of a wide variety of polymers, including rubber, latex, and coatings. Thus far, it has not been possible to use this process to manufacture biodegradable polymers. This research project aims to develop a novel strategy to synthesize biodegradable polymers by emulsion polymerization.  This research project employs tools and concepts from polymer science, catalysis, and reaction engineering and enables the training of both graduate and undergraduate students. An outreach program at the St. Elmo Brady STEM Academy seeks to inspire students from underrepresented groups attending rural schools in central Illinois about science.  Hands-on experimental modules demonstrating polymer synthesis and the importance of polymer recycling for a sustainable environment are being developed.

The objective of this research project is to develop a new methodology for performing ring-opening polymerization of cyclic esters in aqueous dispersions to generate biodegradable polymer latexes.  One aim is to pursue catalytic emulsion polymerization with water-sensitive catalysts by relying on the encapsulation of the catalyst within a hydrophobic capsule dispersed in water, where the shell of this capsule is permeable to the monomer but not to water. Following a top down approach, micrometer-sized block copolymer capsules prepared using a microfluidic technique will be used initially to establish a proof-of-concept. These large capsules permit the determination of the rate of polymerization and rate of transport, information that can be used to develop a model to predict the potential of more scalable, seeded emulsion ring-opening polymerization with nanometer-sized capsules. The microstructure of the block copolymers used to form the semipermeable shell of the capsules are being tuned to increase monomer transport while decreasing the rate of transport of water. Optimization of the rates should allow for the capsules to be decreased in size to tens of nanometers, leading to the first seeded catalytic ring-opening polymerization in aqueous dispersion.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

por.por_cntn:
Polymer latex, the product of aqueous emulsion polymerizations, represents 10% of today's plastic products. Unfortunately, so far, only non-biodegradable polymers are compatible with this process and thus, latex-based products are continuously accumulating in the environment. The lack of biodegradable polymer latex is directly related to the extreme water sensitivity of the polymerization catalyst. The water-sensitive catalyst is incompatible with traditional emulsion techniques for latex materials. Our work has focused on developing a new polymerization technique to produce biodegradable polymer latexes to help bridge the gap in the sustainability of the polymer industry. We have developed a reactor engineering strategy to perform water-sensitive polymerization in an aqueous dispersion. The droplet-based microfluidic encapsulation process yields polymer particles that could not be made using any other methods. This droplet encapsulation method has been shown to temporarily shield the water-sensitive catalyst allowing polymerization to occur in an aqueous dispersion. Additionally, we systematically investigated the process formulation parameters (droplet viscosity, surface tension, and hydrophobicity) that govern the stability of the droplets during generation, flow, and collection. Through a deep understanding of the formulation parameters, we can easily tune the catalyst stability within the droplet. This project has opened the door to developing biodegradable polymer latex. In the past year, we have demonstrated the versatility of our encapsulation approach by expanding to other water-sensitive polymerization catalysts to produce polyether particles. These positive results highlight our encapsulation methodology’s potential to be compatible with other fast water-sensitive polymerizations. Future avenues of this work are focused on expanding to other application areas for these biodegradable polymer particles. Specifically, these polymer particles have potential use in the controlled release of an active ingredient for drug delivery. We are currently exploring controlled encapsulation and release studies with various polymer particles with different formulations. The undergraduate students, graduate student, and postdoctoral fellow trained through this grant gained a broad range of technical skills, including fluid mechanics, catalysis, polymer chemistry, reactor design, and microfluidics. This unique training was a key asset when applying for jobs.


Last Modified: 02/10/2022
Modified by: Damien Guironnet
